docs.abstract: Experiments by Government neuroscientists show that cannibidiol, one ingredient in marijuana, is powerful antioxidant that can prevent much of brain cell death associated with stroke, without marijuana's psychoactive effect; research involves only rat brain tissue (Health Watch column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE medical use of marijuana is controversial for a simple, obvious reason: In addition to the benefits, like relief for cancer-related nausea, patients get high. But one marijuana ingredient may have significant therapeutic value without the psychoactive effect, according to a study by Government neuroscientists, among them a Nobel laureate. In test tube experiments, the ingredient, cannibidiol, prevented more than half of the brain cell death associated with stroke, according to results published in the July issue of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Cannibidiol proved to be a powerful antioxidant, neutralizing some of the ravages caused by strokes. The effect was far greater than that of other antioxidants, including vitamins A and C.
